variety of circumstances. Hydrophobic core/shell CdSe/ZnS QDs were used for Ni
organic solvent. A similar non-linear dependence of fluorescence response on Ni
was observed [43]. In CdS QD sensors, the correlation was found to be linear at low concentration
and it became non-linear when a high Ni
sensing performance was found to be dependent on pH condition [45]. Thioglycolic acid capped
CdTe semiconductor in aqueous solution was applied as the fluorescence sensor, which could
without any tangible influence of a few interfering ions [46]. Imidazole modified
carbon dots were also employed for photoluminescence sensors with limit of detection of 0.93 × 10
mol/L [47]. Compared to those sensors, the present SnO
develop photoluminescence sensors, which take advantages of the chemical stability, non-toxicity
and low cost. On the other hand, highly sensitive spectroscopic techniques, such as inductively
coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), inductively coupled plasma optic emission
spectrometry (ICP-OES) and square wave anodic stripping voltammetric (SWASV), provide precise
results with low limit of detection [48–50]. For example, the limits of detection of ICP-OES are 1.2,
usually of high cost and need complex operations by experienced staffs. The present
QDs would be beneficial to the design of in situ devices for heavy
It is noted that selectivity is an essential characteristics in the detection of heavy metal ions,
because they usually coexist in the contaminated water. However, the present SnO
fluorescence response to all of them. It is necessary to develop the ability to discriminate among
heavy metal ions for a practical sensor. The technique using a neural network is one of the
candidates for the potential device, which contains a sensor array with various sensing properties,
e.g., sensors with various Sn concentrations. Each sensor in the array would be trained by a series of
fluorescence responses to an individual type of heavy metal ion or a mixture of them. Then, the
device would acquire the ability of discrimination to a specific type of heavy metal ion after a group
of fluorescence responses is collected. In addition, the heavy metal ions of Cd
were investigated in the present work because they are typical pollutants in the environment. These
heavy metal ions are representative pollutants, which were used to develop SnO
photoluminescence sensors. Other heavy metal ions, such as Cu
need to be investigated as target pollutants in further researches. There were four different
background solutions in the present work, including deionized water, deionized water with 10 ppm
, reclaimed water and sea water. All of them were used to check the validity of SnO
. Although the prepared QDs were able to detect Ni
sensor, the sensor performances are different in those background solutions. Therefore, it was

]. Compared to those sensors, the present SnO
showpromising properties to develop photoluminescence sensors, which take advantages of the chemical
stability, non-toxicity and low cost. On the other hand, highly sensitive spectroscopic techniques, such
as inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), inductively coupled plasma optic emission

]. However, these techniques are usually of high
cost and need complex operations by experienced staffs. The present photoluminescence sensor of SnO
QDs would be beneficial to the design of in situ devices for heavy metal ions in contaminated water.
It is noted that selectivity is an essential characteristics in the detection of heavy metal ions, because
they usually coexist in the contaminated water. However, the present SnO
response to all of them. It is necessary to develop the ability to discriminate among heavy metal ions for a
practical sensor. The technique using a neural network is one of the candidates for the potential device,
which contains a sensor array with various sensing properties, e.g., sensors with various Sn concentrations.
Each sensor in the array would be trained by a series of fluorescence responses to an individual type of
heavy metal ion or a mixture of them. Then, the device would acquire the ability of discrimination to a
specific type of heavy metal ion after a group of fluorescence responses is collected. In addition, the heavy
were investigated in the present work because they are typical
pollutants in the environment. These heavy metal ions are representative pollutants, which were used to
QD photoluminescence sensors. Other heavy metal ions, such as Cu
, will need to be investigated as target pollutants in further researches. There were four different
background solutions in the present work, including deionized water, deionized water with 10 ppmFe
reclaimed water and sea water. All of themwere used to check the validity of SnO
. Although the prepared QDs were able to detect Ni
ions as a photoluminescence sensor, the sensor
performances are different in those background solutions. Therefore, it was necessary to study the SnO
QDproperties in a diversity of background solutions so that it can be put into practical use.
